text: that was that really kind of was a
turning point for me um that piece of
music I'm not sure it's my most
successful piece of music because it was
a little tough because we had three
choreographers working on the dance and
so they were all working on a different
piece so to me that piece sort of feels
like three different pieces but but what
was wonderful is we were in a studio
working and the dancers I would play a
sound and normally I don't play for
people you know I don't perform I'm very
self-conscious about playing but in the
situation I had to and so I did I came
in with without having having really
written anything a couple little ideas
and I ran a tape recorder and I would
just play a couple of things and the
dancers would start moving and I love
dance I mean I I was a a very bad but
you know a figure skater when I grew up
I danced and to me music is motion and I
largely now figure out my music by
dancing because what would happen is I'd
play something and these incredible
bodies it was pous they'd start moving
and it would be like oh my gosh I played
this note and I just made you do that
you know so and then then I'd watch them
and then I'd play something else and
then they'd move and suddenly I was
playing Way Beyond myself improvising
Way Beyond Myself when later when I
listened to the recording I was like wow
that was me that that's really good but
it's because I was so playing to them so
I realized that and and that piece that
I wrote I it ended up being called
dissolution that piece brought textures
and ideas out of me and out of the band
that were far less typically Jazz than
what I'd written because I was writing
for motion I wasn't writing with a
historic template of an idiom coming at
me from behind but I was purely writing
to the abstraction of movement you know
it it's maybe like almost I went to this
Kandinsky show at you know at the
Guggenheim that's so amazing and he was
looking to music to find abstraction in
in his painting and maybe the movement
helped me really find
something something else in in my sound
so um yeah and and now like I say I I
really I can't almost write a piece
without dancing it helps me figure out
when I was talking about timing it helps
me figure out the timing of the piece
because your body tells you it's hard
for my mind to tell me what's too long
or what's too short but if I start
dancing and moving around my panel I'm
like or you know and I'm just I put I
I'll play it into a recorder I put on
headphones and then I start moving I say
oh no I need to I need more time to to
do what I want to do or no that's
hanging on too long I can't come up with
anything else so my neighbors must think
I'm nuts they they see me you know it's
New York you see does a lot of
Apartments looking right in my window
whatever those poems it's Carlos Dron di
andrai of sort of the way I I guess it's
pronounced and he's a Brazilian poet and
these poems are they're so much like
little stories and I was really scared
when Don Upshaw came to me and wanted me
to write for her I I said okay Don I've
never written really for words I've
never written for a classical singer
I've never written for classical
Orchestra there's nothing about this
that's going to spell success you know
but it ended up happening that when I
sat down to write I loved it because the
words they gave me the first of all they
gave me the Rhythm you know one poem
starts Clara strolled in the garden in
the morning Clara strolled in the garden
in the morning I mean there's only it
has to have a certain Lil to it for it
to sound like it's being spoken then it
also gives you the feeling of what that
is you know a certain kind of tonality
that you might want to have depending
what kind of composer you are and how
you view that and so I felt like it just
it gave me limitations but opened up you
know worlds in me so um it opened up my
imagination it it told me where it wants
to go as opposed to me sitting there in
that room with no light switch just
saying come up with something you know
you've got a 15minute commission and you
sit there and you go oh what do I write
you know so I I love literature it has
to be something I feel passionate about
I mean these poems are killer poems
they're
wonderful
